description: From French attitude, from Italian attitudine (“attitude, aptness”), from Medieval Latin aptitūdō (“aptitude”) and actitūdō (“acting, posture”), from Latin aptō and actitō. Doublet of aptitude.

entries.meaning: The position of the body or way of carrying oneself.
examples: The ballet dancer walked with a graceful attitude.
Don't give me your negative attitude.
You've got a nice attitude today.
He doesn't take attitude from anybody.
I asked the waiter for a clean fork and all I got was attitude.

entries.meaning: (aeronautics, nautical, engineering) The orientation of a vehicle or other object relative to the horizon, direction of motion, other objects, etc.
examples: The airliner had to land with a nose-up attitude after the incident.

entries.meaning: (ballet) A position similar to arabesque, but with the raised leg bent at the knee.
examples: Blasis was a man of many accomplishments. He invented the ballet position of attitude and codified the ballet technique of that time, distinguishing three types of dancers: the serious, the demi-caractère, and the comic dancer.

verbs.description: attitude (third-person singular simple present attitudes, present participle attituding, simple past and past participle attituded)

entries.meaning: To assume or to place in a particular position or orientation; to pose.
examples: […]  nymphs of quality, formed for the offices of love and of conversation, are attituded about her, each star set as it were in surrounding satellites of admirers; […]

entries.meaning: To express an attitude through one's posture, bearing, tone of voice, etc.
examples: He attituded his way over to me, got up close, and just stood there looking at me, trying to appear threatening.
